There are loosely hung electrical extension cords along the wall and a watering hose stored in loop on a vertical stand in
the flight cage to which two Harris' Hawks, two Great Horned Owls and a Barn Owl have access. Extension cords that the
birds can access may cause injury or death if bitten or if the bird becomes entangled. Birds may become entangled in a
hose, especially those animals that are flight-restricted and have limited mobility. Housing facilities for birds must be
designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird housed in them. They must be kept in
good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the welfare of
the birds within.
Correct by 30 September 2025.

There is no documentation that the contingency plan has been reviewed by the exhibitor in the past year. On the
paperwork provided, the last date of review is June 2024. Failure to regularly review the contingency plan may result in
out-of-date information, delays in emergency response and subsequent injury to animals. The plan must be reviewed by
the exhibitor on at least an annual basis to ensure that it adequately addresses the criteria listed in paragraph (a) of this
section. Each licensee must maintain documentation of their annual reviews, including documenting any amendments or
changes made to their plan since the previous year's review. Review documentation must be made available to APHIS
upon request.
Correct by 30 September 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
